In a jumbled discussion about climate change during the first presidential debate on Sept. 29, Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden denounced the Green New Deal.
“The Green New Deal is not my plan,” he said. “…I don’t support the Green New Deal.”

But skeptics on social media say the former vice president hasn’t been consistent in his messaging about the ambitious bill, introduced by Rep. Alexandria Ocasio Cortez, D-N.Y., and Sen. Ed Markey, D-Mass.
“Biden Says He Doesn’t Support Green New Deal, But His Campaign Site Says He Does!” a Facebook post reads.
The Facebook user that made the post did not respond to USA TODAY’s request for comment and clarification.
Fact check:Claims that Hunter Biden received $3.5M from Russia are unproven, lack context
Biden has never fully signed on to the Green New Deal, but his plan isn’t all that different.
At the debate, Biden did say point-blank that he doesn’t support the Green New Deal. But in broader context, he said he supports the “Biden Plan” as an alternative.
“I support the Biden plan that I put forward – the Biden Plan, which is different than what (President Donald Trump) calls the ‘radical’ Green New Deal,” he said at the debate.
Biden revealed a revamped climate plan – called “The Biden Plan for a Clean Energy Revolution and Environmental Justice” – after failing to impress young climate activists with his original one.

The plan differs from the Green New Deal in a number of ways, particularly pertaining to the social issues linked to Ocasio-Cortez and Markey’s bill. The Green New Deal calls for universal jobs and health care; Biden’s plan does not.
More:'I beat the socialist': Biden tacks to the center in fight with Trump over Rust Belt moderates

On other issues, though, the Biden Plan and Green New Deal aren’t too different. Biden’s plan calls the Green New Deal a “crucial framework” for meeting climate challenges, citing two core values Biden sees as similar between the two: the need to act on climate change with more ambition, and the idea that the environment and economy are connected.
The core promise of Biden’s policy is to achieve net-zero emissions of greenhouse gases by 2050, and the Green New Deal has that same goal.

While Trump tried to stoke the flames between moderate and liberal Democrats, saying Biden “lost the radical left” by distancing himself from the Green New Deal, both the bill’s creators said they’d still support Biden – and that his lack of support for the progressive bill isn’t new.
“I support the Green New Deal and I’m voting for Joe Biden,” Markey tweeted Sept. 29.

“Our differences are exactly why I joined Biden’s Climate Unity Task Force – so we could set aside our differences & figure out an aggressive climate plan to address the planetary crisis at our feet,” Ocasio-Cortez tweeted after former Trump adviser Kellyanne Conway shared Biden's comments during the debate.
Fact check:No evidence Biden wore wire at Ohio debate

We rate the claim that what Biden has said versus what he presents on his website about the Green New Deal is inconsistent as MISSING CONTEXT. Biden's climate change plan on his website calls the Green New Deal a "crucial framework" for meeting climate challenges, but his policy proposal differs from it in some ways.
